news.title: The Year’s Strangest Romance Is Also a Perfect Pairing. Let Me Explain.
news.text:
Sign up for the Slatest to get the most insightful analysis, criticism, and advice out there, delivered to your inbox daily.

2025 was a bad year for everything, so why wouldn’t it also be a bad year for anyone who believes in love? Even in dystopia, divorces and breakups raged on: Nicole Kidman and her pocket-sized Australian Keith Urban, Bronwyn Newport and her evil husband on The Real Housewives of Salt Lake City, and seemingly everyone from Love Island called it quits on their relationships this year. Even Steve and Emily Guttenberg didn’t make it.

But nestled amid all this loss was one victory for the year that reminds us that love is real, especially when it’s between two lovable losers. At the beginning of December, Katy Perry hard-launched her new relationship just a few months after ending her six-year engagement with Orlando Bloom, in a 13-slide Instagram dump of photos from the Tokyo leg of her world tour. Tucked among pictures of sumo wrestlers and jiggling pancake stacks were a few shots of her and her new man eating sushi and gazing at a light exhibition.

Her new boyfriend is unlike anyone else she’s ever dated. He isn’t a B- or C-list celebrity like her first husband, Russell Brand, or her ex-fiancé. He isn’t a fellow creative, or even someone you’d expect Perry to run into at her neighborhood Erewhon. Somehow, against all odds—and lord, were there ever odds—Perry’s new boyfriend is none other than Canada’s only living fuckable prime minister, Justin Trudeau.

Over the summer, TMZ first broke the news that the two were seeing each other, publishing grainy photos of the two of them out for dinner at Le Violon, a fine-dining restaurant in Montreal. The date was surprising to everyone, including those closest to Trudeau, partly because it was such an intense one. “It was a 14-, 15-hour date,” said one Ottawa-based political operative with close ties to Trudeau, on the condition of anonymity. “I was like, Why is Justin going on lesbian dates with Katy Perry?”

In mid-October, around (Canadian) Thanksgiving, according to people in Trudeau’s circle, he gathered a few of his closest friends and political confidants to tell them the relationship was real. Two weeks later, he and Perry were gleefully holding hands in Paris while celebrating her 41st birthday. “He was saying in mid-November he’s going to introduce her to his close guy friends, his childhood friends,” the Ottawa operative said. That’s a big deal for Trudeau; he’s maintained the same circle of friends since he was just the son of Pierre Trudeau, the 15th prime minister. Perry is the first woman he’s brought so closely into his fold since his 2023 divorce.

If you’ve been paying attention to the trajectories of these two once-loved figures of the 2010s, this coupling makes perfect sense for both of them. “Neither one has had a very good—let’s call it 48 months,” said Lainey Lui, founder and editor of Lainey Gossip and co-anchor on Canada’s eTalk. “He got divorced, lost his job, and needed a comeback story. She also left her relationship and she’s not the pop superstar at that level that she once was.” In October, Lui wrote about the two of them, “Two people in their flop era getting together to un-flop themselves is a good move!” Love, after all, is a perfect way for two celebrities lacking relevancy to find it once again.

The politician and the pop star are a misshapen romance novel come to life: They’ve connected during respective fallow periods in their careers and personal lives, each seeking a new way to enter public life. Perry was once the ultimate girl-boss raunchy white-girl popstar for the millennial generation, churning out steady hits and culture-defining music videos and performances. Trudeau was once a promising progressive hero for many Canadians and Americans who hoped his youth and nepo-baby bona fides would revolutionize Canadian politics and life.

The tide turned on each of them after their public peaks, and they separately had remarkable falls from grace. Perry’s latest album, 143, was a critical and commercial dud. (A song called “Woman’s World” produced by the guy Kesha sued for sexual assault? A pretty tough sell!) And while she has stumped for Democratic candidates in Trudeau’s flavo(u)r, like Hillary Clinton and Kamala Harris, she’s maintained close ties to controversial figures like Jeff Bezos while supporting Republicans like Rick Caruso, alienating her more liberal fanbase. (Don’t even get me started on all the dying nuns and the veterans she keeps suing.)

Trudeau, meanwhile, disappointed progressives and infuriated Conservatives over his time as prime minister. Those who voted for him grew tired of slick talk and little action around electoral reform or Indigenous rights. Right-wingers pointed to the skyrocketing cost of living in Canada, and the Liberal government’s mismanagement of immigration. No one seemed to think he could face Trump in a battle over tariffs after a brutalizing pandemic that shuttered so much of the country. But, plainly put, people just got sick of his shit: His gentle-parenting manner, sometimes bordering on condescension, stopped charming Canadians the way it once did. At the end of 2024, a few months before he stepped down, his approval rating was around 33 percent.

Trudeau and Perry are icons of a political generation now mostly forgotten, namely a kind of middle-of-the-road liberalism that’s useless against MAGA-style Republicanism and tedious compared to Gen Z and Alpha leftism. They come from political and cultural worlds that no longer exist. No wonder they make such a perfect, if improbable, match. As we wind down yet another worst-year-of-our-lives, there’s so little to root for. But maybe these two crazy kids are the right place for us to put some hope for the future.

Justin, as Canadians called him through his infancy, into his adulthood, and even through his time as prime minister, was made for public life. Notorious since his 1971 Christmas Day birth, Trudeau was born to father Pierre, the prime minister from 1968 to 1979 and again from 1980 to 1984. His mother, Margaret, was nearly 30 years younger than her husband, infamous for being beautiful, complicated, and flighty. Pierre is, still, one of the most beloved political figures in Canadian history, notorious for being clever, effective, and a little rude. (The night that Pierre and his Liberal Party were defeated in 1979, his estranged wife was clubbing in Studio 54 instead of tending to her family. She remains one of the most beloved ex-wives in Canadian history.) When they divorced, Pierre had primary custody of the boys, but Trudeau was always described as a “mommy’s boy.”

Trudeau has always been famous and well-off, but the children of Canadian politicians aren’t the same as American ones. “Growing up as the prime minister’s son, there’s not a lot of wealth involved. It’s not like he grew up going on private jets,” said the Ottawa politico. “But everyone knew who he was, and so he naturally is a guarded person.” Perry isn’t the first famous person he’s dated, but she’s certainly the closest to his level of international recognition. That’s at least one thing they have in common: “It’s probably nice to be with someone who can understand not wanting to have your picture taken if you’re eating breakfast somewhere,” the operative said.

When Richard Nixon visited Ottawa in 1972, when Trudeau was a few months old, he toasted him as “the future Prime Minister of Canada.” He became the custodian of the family legacy, in part through tragedy: His middle brother Alexandre was never much for the public eye, and youngest brother Michel died in an avalanche in the late ’90s. Pierre died in 2000, when Trudeau was 28, and his fame exploded in earnest when he delivered a eulogy that was broadcast across the country. “Until that moment,” Macleans wrote about Trudeau in 2000, “he had been almost unknown to Canadians. But when he started his eulogy he had their undivided attention.”

When he was younger, Trudeau often talked about wanting to become a teacher. (He did teach briefly, at a high school, where he famously did brownface in 2001, which somehow didn’t kill his political future.) But his life would never be his own, and his entrance into federal politics felt inevitable. “His political beginning was a worldwide televised event,” Lui says. “That moment is almost storybook, almost cinematic. Every camera was pointed at him and he captured the world’s attention. His public life is defined by a moment like that. His ‘private’ life post-office is still going to be a show.” Pierre could be a bully, a brute, and was known as “Swinging Pierre” for his many sexual exploits. Trudeau’s touch, politically and personally, was always gentler. “He is more of his mother’s son,” said Shannon Proudfoot, a feature writer for the Ottawa bureau at the Globe and Mail. “He’s more expressive, emotive, heart-on-the-sleeve, touchy-feely.” Margaret used to call Trudeau “a very romantic boy.”

And god, did he ever love to perform romance. For 18 years, he was married to Canada’s greatest cornball, Sophie Grégoire, before they split up in 2023. Grégoire was a well-known television host, but as Trudeau’s wife, she was perhaps best known for spontaneously bursting into song at a Martin Luther King Day tribute. (One source close to Grégoire explained her enthusiasm: “People outside of Canada don’t get it. She isn’t crazy. She’s just French Canadian.”) Trudeau’s love life has always been on display, and while the United States inched closer and closer to the first Trump administration, Justin and Sophie were a resplendent and attractive Canadian alternative. In a 2015 issue of Vogue, Trudeau was photographed not just as a young political upstart, but as a public husband, caressing his wife’s rump in a magazine. Have you ever seen a more romantic boy in your life?

But according to those close to Trudeau’s office, Grégoire was looking forward to duties akin to those of a first lady. In Canada, that sort of gig doesn’t really exist despite the early days of photo spreads and the official visits to India and Washington. “I think she thought it would be more glitzy and glam, more state visits,” said the Ottawa operative. “Reality hits, and, like, 24 Sussex is uninhabitable because there’s asbestos and rats in it. We don’t have an Air Force One. The planes were so old that we constantly had to refuel in Gander.”

Katy Perry, one assumes, does not refuel in Gander. Who knows if she’s even been to Newfoundland? But maybe there’s some novelty for the two of them here: Trudeau finally gets to date someone who understands fame and excess as much as he does, and she gets to date someone impressed by a private jet.

You won’t find much reporting about Trudeau and Perry in the Canadian press. Canadian journalists don’t often busy themselves with the personal lives of politicians, in or out of office. “It’s not a protective, carrying-water norm,” Proudfoot says. “It’s a collective code that we focus on the work and not the person.”

Earlier this year, there were rumblings that Trudeau was dating a lawyer based in Newfoundland. No one reported on it officially—the extracurricular activities of an outgoing prime minister would be too lurid for a Canadian audience—but photos of the two of them holding hands surfaced on X and in countless Canadian group chats. “Everyone knew, and it was like, Hey, isn’t that fascinating?” Proudfoot says. “But what is there for us to seize on?”

According to people close to Trudeau, there was no overlap between the two relationships, and Trudeau was clear with her that they weren’t in any kind of exclusive relationship. He met Perry in February at the Invictus Games in Vancouver, and then later attended her Montreal concert with his daughter. It was Perry who apparently reached out to spend time together privately, and almost immediately, that previous relationship was over. And after that hours-long date in Montreal, there was only one girl for him, and it’s the one who got violently slimed at the 2010 Kid’s Choice Awards.

Perry seemed to fall for him fast, too, which isn’t surprising if you ask at least a few women who’ve known him over the years. “He’s very sexy in person, in terms of how he carries his body. He’s charming and flirty to a lot of women,” said the Ottawa political reporter who asked to remain anonymous. “It doesn’t surprise me that months later, she’s like, I’m going to Canada, let me reach out to this guy and he can show me around.” It makes sense if you think about the entire ethos of Trudeau’s early political campaign: Man Hot. Down about politics? Look at Man Forearms. Worried about the economy? The bluest of Blue Eyes™ right here. The chief criticism around Trudeau was that he was all talk and all looks, but talk and looks are pretty good qualities in a boyfriend.

Katy Perry is coming off a streak of resounding losses, both personal and professional. Her recent split from Orlando Bloom is her second divorce after she was famously dumped by her first husband, Russell Brand, mere moments before going on stage in Brazil in late 2011.Her current tour has been panned as has her music, and for much of the spring and summer, there seemed to be entire TikTok accounts dedicated to tracking how undersold her shows were. For the last decade, Perry has struggled with proving authenticity to her audience, who are less enthralled by her glittery costumes and Dennis the Menace personality. “The knock on Katy was that it was girlboss feminism,” Lui says. “But whatever the equivalent of girlboss feminism is as a prime minister, that would be Trudeau.” Perry’s romance with Trudeau is perfect in part because their form of political engagement—and the futility of it—is exactly in sync.

Among Ottawa reporters and those close to Trudeau, the pairing feels both ludicrous and exactly right. “It registered to me as an acid trip Mad Libs. It makes no sense, but on another level, it makes all the sense in the world,” said Proudfoot. For years while in office, Trudeau was a deeply unpopular figure in Canada, a joint enemy across the political spectrum. Now, he’s just some Canadian celebrity with international name recognition. “He’s yesterday’s man, and we’ve moved on,” Proudfoot says. “Maybe that’s why his relationship with Katy Perry is this object of amused fascination in Ottawa: She is the embodiment of the 2015 zeitgeist in 2025. It’s astonishingly symmetrical.” Their politics—or rather, the way their politics have aged—is what unites them.

Maybe their compatibility is much, much simpler than all this intellectualizing about mid-aughts centrism. These are two cornballs who have found each other, thank god. Even Perry’s hard launch of their relationship is full of cringey, corny sweetness, including Trudeau gazing at her while she eats a mini uni. It’s cute! It’s mortifying. They deserve each other, which you can say either as a dig or as a kindness.

Through Perry, Trudeau has an opportunity to be the good guy—something he loves being, as any Canadian who’s suffered through one of his speeches about gender parity knows. “I think about the pictures of them coming out of the restaurant in Paris for her birthday,” Lui said. “He’s performing the role of ideal boyfriend in an A.I.-written rom-com: The pop star is on the road but her boyfriend surprises her for dinner.”

Trudeau, at least, is playing the role. According to those closest to him, what he likes best about Perry is how engaged of a mother she is. (He, after all, sewed his son’s Halloween costumes even while he was in office, ducking out early to pick up fabric on the way home for Hadrian’s pants.) “This is the fantasy in the rom-com: The single mom who is the star wants to be appreciated, and also treated, indulged,” Lui said. “And here he is. He looks great in a suit!”

You’ll keep seeing Trudeau and Perry in 2026, rest assured. “It’s definitely not a flash,” said the Ottawa operative. “It has legs.” Trudeau’s former staff have gone from privately shrugging their shoulders about this particular exploit to accepting it as a real, important part of his life.They’re getting closer and more public. Trudeau is, notably, including Perry in his diplomacy work; their Tokyo hard launch was around a visit to Japan’s former prime minister, and not just her tour stop. Not quite a state visit, but a far cry from whatever it is that Orlando Bloom does for a living. (Selling cruises?)

Perry has already met much of Trudeau’s circle in Ottawa. But maybe the greatest reveal of the intimacy between them isn’t in what they’re letting us see—public hand-holding, dinners out, Instagram posts. Rather, it’s in what those close to Trudeau say he calls his new girlfriend. “Katheryn. Her real name,” the Ottawa insider said, sighing, happy for Trudeau but a little sicked out by it too. “Never Katy.”
news.summary: Trudeau was all talk and all looks as prime minister, but talk and looks are pretty good qualities in a boyfriend.

news.title: These signs show a new force is coming to clean out the White House
news.text:
The media is freaking out over a new Rasmussen poll that found:

“A majority of voters under 40 want a democratic socialist to win the White House in the next presidential election.“… 51 percent of Likely U.S. Voters ages 18 to 39 would like to see a democratic socialist candidate win the 2028 presidential election. Thirty-six percent (36 percent) don’t want a democratic socialist to win in 2028, while 17 percent are not sure…“Among the youngest cohort (ages 18-24) of voters, 57 percent want a democratic socialist to win the next presidential election…“Among those who voted for Kamala Harris in last year’s presidential election, 78 percent would like to see a democratic socialist candidate win the 2028 presidential election…” (emphasis added).

I was on Ali Velshi’s MSNOW show discussing this, along with Michael Green who recently wrote a thought-provoking article about how the official poverty line in America is completely out-of-date and out of touch with the needs of most Americans. I shared a few statistics from my recent book :

When, in 1957, my dad bought the house I grew up in, the average cost of a single-family home in America was about 2.2 times the average annual wage. Today it’s more than ten times the average wage.When my Boomer generation was the same age as today’s Millennials, we owned a bit over 22 percent of the nation’s wealth; Millennials today control only about 4 percent of the country’s wealth (and it’s the same for Zoomers).From the 1930s right up until the Reagan Revolution, it was possible for seniors to live comfortably on Social Security alone; Reagan undid that with his “reforms” so today that’s nearly impossible.When I ran my first seriously successful business in the early 1970s, it cost me around $35/month for comprehensive health insurance for each of my 18 employees; at that time hospitals and health insurance companies were required by Michigan law (where I lived; most other states were identical) to be run as non-profits. Today, health insurance can be as much as one-fifth of a company’s payroll expense.When Reagan came into office in 1981, a single wage earner could support a family with a middle-class lifestyle, and fully 65 percent of us were in the middle class (up from around 20 percent in the 1930s). Today, after 44 years of Reaganomics, it takes two full-time people to achieve the same status, which triggers huge childcare expenses, which is part of why only 43 percent of us are middle class .

FDR’s great — and successful — Democratic Socialist experiment following the Republican Great Depression was to drive the economy from the bottom up, reversing the “Horse and Sparrow” trickle-down economics and deregulation of the Harding, Coolidge, and Hoover administrations that provoked the Great Crash.

He did that by:

Expanding the notion of the commons — the stuff we all collectively own and is administered or funded and regulated by government — to include free public education nationwide (and cheap college), old-age retirement (Social Security), and public power and transportation systems (Tennessee Valley Authority, federal support for local transit, roads and highways).Legalizing unions, an effort that was so successful that when Reagan came into office fully a third of us had good union jobs and, because they set the local wage floors, two-thirds of Americans had the equivalent of a union wage and benefit package.Establishing a minimum wage on which a single worker could raise a family of three and still stay above the federal poverty level (today’s federal minimum wage is $7.25: adjusted with the Consumer Price Index, that $1.60 minimum wage in 1968 is equivalent to about $14.90 an hour in 2025 dollars).

In the years since, we’ve continued to expand the commons by establishing national single-payer healthcare systems for low-income people (Medicaid) and retired people (Medicare), both of which came out of LBJ’s Democratic Socialist program that he called The Great Society.

Meanwhile, Republicans and a few neoliberal Democrats have pushed back against these Democratic Socialist programs that made the American middle class the first in the history of the world to exceed more than half the population.

Reagan’s war on unions has cut our union membership down to well under 10 percent in the private sector.His gutting federal funding for education has exploded college costs to the point where three generations are saddled with over $2 trillion in debt that can’t be discharged by bankruptcy.Reagan’s tax cuts for the rich (from 74 percent down to 27 percent) and corporations tripled the national debt (from $800 billion to $2.4 trillion) just in his eight years; since then the four GW Bush and Trump tax cuts have, when combined with Reagan’s, produced a $38 trillion national debt so big that we now spend more on servicing their debt than we do on our defense budget or would on administering a national healthcare system.

Back in the 1940s, after the incredible success of the New Deal, President Roosevelt wanted to further expand the commons by expanding the scope of his Democratic Socialist programs. Just before he died, he proposed a “Second Bill of Rights” that included:

“The right to a useful and remunerative job in the nation’s industries, shops, farms, or mines. (Unionization and an above-poverty-level minimum wage.)“The right to earn enough to provide adequate food, clothing, and recreation. (Ditto and government as the employer of last resort.)“The right of every farmer to raise and sell products at a return that gives his family a decent living. (Don’t manipulate farm prices with stupid tariff wars, etc., and make the government the purchaser of last resort.)“The right of every businessperson, large and small, to trade free from unfair competition and domination by monopolies. (Break up the giant corporations and encourage average people to start small businesses, including with loan supports.)“The right of every family to a decent home. (Today this would mean no more corporations, hedge funds, and foreign billionaires owning single-family homes to squeeze us dry by jacking up rents.)“The right to adequate medical care and the opportunity to enjoy good health. (FDR favored a single-payer healthcare system like Medicare for All.)“The right to protection from the economic fears of old age, sickness, accident, and unemployment (i.e., robust Social Security, Medicare, and unemployment insurance).“The right to a good education.” (Free or inexpensive college, quality public schools in every community.)

Much to the chagrin of my Republican-activist father, my grandfather (a 1917 Norwegian immigrant) frequently and proudly described himself as a socialist. When I asked him what he meant, he always pointed me to FDR, the New Deal, and his proposed Second Bill of Rights.

And here we are again.

My grandfather’s generation saw up-close and firsthand the tax-cutting and deregulation binge of the Roaring 20s (which were only “roaring” for the morbidly rich), and then had the lived experience of watching FDR put the country back together and create the world’s first widespread middle class.

Millennials and Zoomers today are seeing the same thing, between the Bush Housing Crash of 2008, the botched Covid Crash of 2020, and the GOP’s relentless program to drive the wealth of the nation into the money bins of the billionaires who own that party.

They see the example of most European countries, where the commons includes college (many will actually pay you a stipend to attend), healthcare, and daycare/preschool, and union density is often well above 80%. Housing is subsidized or heavily regulated, leading several to have essentially ended homelessness. Giant corporate monopolies are prohibited and local small businesses are encouraged.

Europeans call these programs Democratic Socialism or social democracy, and young Americans clearly are enthusiastic about bringing the “European Dream” to this country.

My sense is that — much like in the 1930s — a significant majority of Americans are sick of the neoliberal “let the rich run things because they know best” bullshit that Republicans, “Tech Bros,” and a shrinking minority of on-the-take Democratic politicians embrace.

Meanwhile, nobody’s sure why the Democratic National Committee (DNC) is refusing to release the autopsy they did of the 2024 election, producing speculation it may have uncovered examples of Russian and Republican manipulation of both voters and the vote, but I’m guessing the real reason is that the neoliberals who largely run the DNC saw feedback that reflected the Rasmussen poll I opened this article with.

The exploding popularity of progressive politicians from Zohran Mamdani to Bernie Sanders, Jasmine Crockett, and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez aren’t an anomaly; they’re a signpost to both electoral and governing success for the next generation of genuinely progressive Democratic politicians.

news.title: Journalist fumes over last-minute pulling of report
news.text:
An internal CBS News battle over a "60 Minutes" story critical of the Trump administration has exploded publicly, with a correspondent charging that it was kept off the air for political reasons and news chief Bari Weiss saying Monday that the story did not "advance the ball."

Two hours before airtime Sunday, CBS announced that the story, in which correspondent Sharyn Alfonsi spoke to deportees who had been sent to El Salvador's notorious CECOT prison, would not be a part of the show. Weiss, the Free Press founder named CBS News editor-in-chief in October, said it was her decision.

The dispute puts one of journalism's most respected brands -- and a frequent target of President Donald Trump -- back in the spotlight and amplifies questions about whether Weiss' appointment was a signal that CBS News was headed in a more Trump-friendly direction.

Alfonsi, in an email sent to fellow "60 Minutes" correspondents, said the story was factually correct and had been cleared by CBS lawyers and its standards division. But the Trump administration had refused to comment for the story, and Weiss wanted a greater effort made to get their point of view.

"In my view, pulling it now after every rigorous internal check has been met is not an editorial decision, it is a political one," Alfonsi wrote in the email. She did not immediately respond to requests for comment from The Associated Press.

Alfonsi said in the email that interviews were sought with or questions directed to -- sometimes both -- the White House, State Department and Department of Homeland Security.

"Government silence is a statement, not a VETO," Alfonsi wrote. "Their refusal to be interviewed is a tactical maneuver designed to kill the story. If the administration's refusal to participate becomes a valid reason to spike a story, we have effectively handed them a 'kill switch' for any reporting they find inconvenient."

"Spike" is a journalist's term for killing a story. But Weiss, in a statement, said she looked forward to airing Alfonsi's piece "when it's ready."

Speaking Monday at the daily CBS News internal editorial call, Weiss was clearly angered by Alfonsi's memo. A transcript of Weiss' message was provided by CBS News.

"The only newsroom I'm interested in running is one in which we are able to have contentious disagreements about the thorniest editorial matters with respect and, crucially, where we assume the best intent of our colleagues," Weiss said. "Anything else is completely unacceptable."

She said that while Alfonsi's story presented powerful testimony about torture at the CECOT prison, The New York Times and other outlets had already done similar work. "To run a story on this subject two months later, we need to do more," she said. "And this is '60 Minutes.' We need to be able to get the principals on the record and on camera."

It wasn't clear whether Weiss' involvement in seeking administration comment was sought. She reportedly helped the newscast arrange interviews with Jared Kushner and Steve Witkoff this past fall to discuss Trump's Middle East peace efforts. Trump was interviewed by Norah O'Donnell on a "60 Minutes" telecast that aired Nov. 2.

Trump has been sharply critical of "60 Minutes." He refused to grant the show an interview before last fall's election, then sued the network over how it handled an interview with election opponent Kamala Harris. CBS's parent company, Paramount Global, agreed to settle the lawsuit by paying Trump $16 million this past summer. More recently, Trump angrily reacted to correspondent Lesley Stahl's interview with former Trump ally-turned-critic Marjorie Taylor Greene.

"60 Minutes" was notably tough on Trump during the first months of his second term, particularly in stories done by correspondent Scott Pelley. In accepting an award from USC Annenberg earlier this month for his journalism, Pelley noted that the stories were aired last spring "with an absolute minimum of interference."

Pelley said that people at "60 Minutes" were concerned about what new ownership installed at Paramount this summer would mean for the broadcast. "It's early yet, but what I can tell you is we are doing the same kinds of stories with the same kind of rigor, and we have experienced no corporate interference of any kind," Pelley said then, according to deadline.com.
news.author: David Bauder The Associated Press
